body: Great report, thanks. I have labelled and added to the backlog.

Nice! This is interesting because we actually test for the proper message. However, in our test we use `ExceptionTypeConstraint` directly, which is not what the syntax creates for us. Classic downside of isolated tests! I'm looking at this since it caught my interest.

There are complications here that could lead us deep in to the building of constraint expressions. However, I can see two pretty simple solutions.

1. `Throws.TypeOf` could return an `ExceptionTypeConstraint` rather than an `ExactTypeConstraint`. That will fix the exact case reported but will not fix either  `Throws.Exception.TypeOf` or `Throws.InstanceOf`, which display the same problem. It would, however, be an improvement.

2. We could modify `ConstraintResult.WriteActualValueTo` so it works just like the corresponding method in `ExceptionTypeConstraintResult` when the actual value is an exception. This is a wide-reaching change so we would have to check to see if there are any problems. I can't think of a situation where the actual value would be an exception and we __wouldn't__ want to see message and stack trace, but there could be one. If we take this approach, we could consider marking `ExceptionTypeConstraint` as obsolete, since it will no longer be necessary.

I'm taking my name off this and marking it as an easy fix. I recommend trying approach 2 first.

All yours. ðŸ˜„ 

What I suggest is that you try the second approach on your fork and see if the more global change breaks anything. If not, we can go ahead with it. If it does, I think the first approach is good enough.

The problem with the second approach is that the actual value could be an exception only in case of `ExceptionTypeConstraintResult`, but in fact even there it isn't. In case of `ExactTypeConstraint`, which `Throws.TypeOf` uses, the actual value is a type, and that makes sense, since it's a type constraint. I see no simple and decent way of modifying `ConstraintResult.WriteActualValueTo` so that works similar to `ExceptionTypeConstraintResult.WriteActualValueTo`. @CharliePoole please tell me if I miss, or misunderstand something. If not, I'm going with the first approach.

Unfortunately the first approach doesn't work either. `Throws.TypeOf` uses `ConstraintExpression.TypeOf` under the hood. It's return type can't be changed to `ExceptionTypeConstraint`, because `ConstraintExpression.TypeOf` constraint is suppose to work with types other than `Exception`. @CharliePoole correct me if I'm wrong.

That issue just stopped looking like an easyfix to me :wink:
Please unassign me from this issue, for a while I wasn't able to find time to do it.
I'd quite like to pick this up as my first contribution, could you assign me please? :)
@rprouse Can you invite @BlakeWills, so we can assign the issue to him

I thought I had a solution to this, but as already mentioned above, the fundamental problem here is that `Throws.TypeOf()` returns `ExactTypeConstraint`, rather than `ExceptionTypeConstraint`.

This is a problem because it forces `ThrowsConstraint.ApplyTo()` to return an instance of `ThrowsConstraintResult`, with the base result set to the caught exceptions type (rather than the actual exception). As mentioned before, this makes sense for a `TypeConstraint`.

I think a potential fix to this issue is to introduce a new `ExceptionConstraintExpression`, who's `TypeOf()` methods return `ExceptionTypeConstraint`, rather than `ExactTypeConstraint`. (This may well be a dumb idea, as it's the first time I've looked at the code, so I don't really understand the architecture / internals.)

@BlakeWills I am going to assign this to @mikkelbu to work with you on this issue.

As for your analysis, I would need to look at the code, but your analysis and possible solution sound like a good start.
